message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The rusty nail suggests a risk of tetanus infection, especially since the patient cannot recall if he had a tetanus shot within the last 5 years. Therefore, administering both Td (tetanus and diphtheria) and TIG (tetanus immune globulin) is the most appropriate next step in management. Cleaning and dressing the wound alone won’t provide sufficient protection against tetanus. Administering Tdap (tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine), which is more commonly given to adolescents, is unnecessary in this case as the patient is already 15 years old, and Td provides sufficient coverage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a puncture wound and there are rusty particles in the base, indicating the possibility of tetanus. The patient had a tetanus shot last at the age of 12, so a Td booster shot is required. Since the wound is dirty, tetanus immune globulin (TIG) should also be administered along with the Td vaccine. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is to administer Td and TIG.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a puncture wound and is unsure of his vaccination history, so he should receive both Td and TIG to prevent tetanus infection. Cleaning the wound alone is not enough to prevent infection.

We refer to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidelines for tetanus management. The patient presents with a puncture wound, which is a tetanus-prone wound. The last tetanus shot was more than 5 years ago, so the patient should receive a tetanus toxoid-containing vaccine (Td) as well as tetanus immune globulin (TIG). Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is to administer Td and TIG. Cleaning and dressing the wound is important, but tetanus prophylaxis is necessary to prevent potentially fatal tetanus infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a puncture wound and has not received a tetanus shot recently. Therefore, he needs both the tetanus vaccine (Td) and tetanus immune globulin (TIG) to prevent the development of tetanus infection. Option A is not enough to prevent tetanus, and options B and C do not include both the vaccine and immune globulin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of a rusty nail puncture, along with the presence of red-brown particles in the wound, strongly suggest a risk of tetanus. Administering both Td (Tetanus, Diphtheria) vaccine and TIG (Tetanus Immune Globulin) is the most appropriate next step in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A puncture wound increases the risk of tetanus, especially if the wound was caused by a rusty nail. The boy's vaccination history is not up to date, so he should receive both Td (tetanus, diphtheria) and TIG (tetanus immune globulin) to provide immediate passive immunity and stimulate active immunity. Simply cleaning and dressing the wound is not enough to prevent tetanus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of rusty nail puncture indicates a high risk for tetanus infection. Both Td and TIG administration are recommended for patients with a contaminated wound and uncertain immunization or immunization status more than 5 years, and for those whose last dose of tetanus vaccine was more than 10 years ago.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the patient is not able to walk on his foot indicates that he has a puncture wound that likely involves deep structures, which could increase the risk of tetanus infection. The presence of rusty nail and debris in the wound also increases this risk. Therefore, administration of both Td and TIG is necessary for tetanus prophylaxis. Cleaning and dressing the wound alone is not sufficient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s last tetanus shot was 3 years ago, and because of the dirty wound, Td and TIG should be administered. Cleaning and dressing the wound alone is not enough, and administering Tdap instead of Td is not recommended in this situation.
